image.altText: A flooded and damaged road on Groote Eylandt.

props.synopsis: The former cyclone has been downgraded to a tropical low following its coastal crossing overnight, but is being forecast to bring heavy rainfall and possible flooding to parts of the NT throughout the week.

title.children: Ex-Tropical Cyclone Megan rapidly weakens to tropical low but heavy rain and flooding still likely

image.altText: Hands holding a mobile phone displaying a gambling app

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory is Australia's least populated jurisdiction, but gambling laws set to be debated — and passed — in the NT parliament this week will govern betting companies across the country. Here's why.

title.children: NT gambling laws are being overhauled. Here's why that will have national consequences

image.altText: Picture of a high-voltage transmission line

props.synopsis: Benchmark electricity prices are set to fall for hundreds of thousands of customers but will rise for others under changes flagged by the country's energy regulator.

title.children: Belated power price relief for some, while other Australians expected to have increased bills

image.altText: Two police officers in uniform face away from the camera

props.synopsis: Images of three certificates allegedly handed out to members of an elite NT Police unit have been revealed, following the lifting of a suppression order by the NT coroner. WARNING: This story contains racist and offensive language and images.

title.children: NT coroner lifts suppression order over Territory Response Group awards

image.altText: A young white woman with blonde hair sitting on a couch with a baby with red hair

props.synopsis: Women say they are being routinely delayed or denied epidurals when giving birth because of mistaken beliefs about their impact on labour.

title.children: 'I felt violated': Samantha asked for an epidural three times during labour and was dismissed each time

image.altText: Uber logo seen on the outside of a building

props.synopsis: When Uber burst into the Australian market more than a decade ago, it came with all guns blazing. As it forks out almost $272 million, what happens next for the platform experts say "flouted the law"?

title.children: Uber 'flouted the law' for years, say experts. Now a compensation lawsuit means the 'cowboy company' is paying the price

image.altText: Vladimir Putin resting his chin on his hand

props.synopsis: The Russian president's reign is set to continue for another six years, but his country faces numerous challenges, including a declining population, a devastating invasion of Ukraine and increasing international isolation, writes Riley Stuart.

title.children: With another term secured, Putin will continue his war in Ukraine. But he may be gearing up for another battle

image.altText: A bag covered in flies.

props.synopsis: They're tiny, yet supremely irritating. Australian bush flies are known for trying to crawl into your nose, eyes and ears and they're on the uptick in Central Australia.

title.children: Bumper year for bush flies in outback NT as hot, humid weather creates perfect breeding conditions

image.altText: A Ukrainian serviceman loads ammunition for a machine gun.

props.synopsis: Ukraine is ammunition-starved and losing ground to Russian troops, but the US hasn't sent weapons in months. Analysts say the situation is already dire on the frontline and there are concerns military funding woes will only get worse.

title.children: Can Ukraine survive its 'shell hunger'? The US aid taps are off and weapons are quickly dwindling

image.altText: Nuclear power station chimneys

props.synopsis: The argument for re-examining the merits of nuclear power in Australia has been countered with concerns about the high cost of building the plants. But the rising price of uranium is another issue — and Australia's place as a major supplier doesn't guarantee cheap power, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: Why corporate Australia won't touch nuclear power

image.altText: A woman speaks to the media as others stand behind.

props.synopsis: The proposed bill would also ban donations from "social harm" industries (e.g. gambling) and police "lies" in election ads. Follow live.

title.children: Crossbenchers want politicians to disclose donations above $1,000 in real-time in a push for election reform

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Greens senator called 'basket weaver' by senior government minister
Jodie Belyea welcomed to the party room

image.altText: Rosa Ellen, with black shirt and blue pants, and shoulder-length blonde hair, stands in an office looking at a phone screen.

props.synopsis: Since January Rosa Ellen has been living without a smartphone. Instead, she uses an old-fashioned, internet-free phone. It's brought unexpected hurdles, but she's found clever ways to manage them.

title.children: When Rosa ditched her smartphone for a 'dumb phone', unexpected challenges arose. Here's how she overcame them

image.altText: A bronze Commonwealth Coat of Arms hangs on a white wall inside a court house. I

props.synopsis: It took a jury just two hours to find Warren Dhamarrandji guilty of murdering his partner in a park in Darwin's northern suburbs, rejecting his defence of diminished responsibility.

title.children: Warren Dhamarrandji found guilty of murder after stabbing partner nine times in broad daylight

image.altText: Courtney Smith with Josh-Thomas laughing

props.synopsis: This is how Josh Thomas and Courtney Smith became chosen family — from hitting it off post-divorce, to refusing to be a sperm donor.

title.children: Courtney Smith wanted her best friend Josh Thomas to be her sperm donor. He had other ideas

image.altText: A customer wheels a trolley past an aisle of a supermarket with ice cream in freezers.

props.synopsis: The Greens will introduce a bill to parliament that would create powers to force Coles and Woolworths to sell parts of their business if they were found to be misusing their market dominance — an idea also backed by the Nationals.

title.children: Coles and Woolworths face Greens push to force break-ups if they abuse market power

image.altText: City office-workers and passers-by watch the ASX board in Sydney

props.synopsis: The Australian share market is flat in early trade, while the Reserve Bank is almost universally tipped to keep interest rates on hold this afternoon. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: RBA to make interest rate decision this afternoon, as ASX flat

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: ASX remains flat at lunch ahead of RBA rates decision
Nvidia unveils brand new flagship AI chip
BoJ in focus:Will Japan end its negative interest rates policy?

image.altText: Lake Argyle

props.synopsis: As the race towards developing green hydrogen plans continues, the Australian government says it's throwing $1.6 million behind a giant billion-dollar project in outback WA.

title.children: First-of-its-kind multi-billion-dollar clean energy project backed by federal government

image.altText: Midnight Oil at the Royal Antler Hotel, Narrabeen, NSW, circa 1971.

props.synopsis: A TV show, radio station and smoke-filled pubs: Peter Garrett explains what drove Australia's rock revolution.

title.children: Midnight Oil never appeared on Countdown. But Peter Garrett says the show changed the band's trajectory

image.altText: A woman in front of a wall of flowers

props.synopsis: Just days after Chaithanya Madhagani's body was found in a wheelie bin in Victoria, two people allegedly broke into her house.

title.children: Two arrests after home of Melbourne woman broken into days after her body was found in regional Victoria

image.altText: A sign states 'You are now entering prison property' outside the Casuarina Prison

props.synopsis: The Aboriginal Legal Service has filed a complaint with the WA Department of Justice, alleging a youth custodial officer made the noises in the cell where teenager Cleveland Dodd took his own life.

title.children: 'Ghost noises' allegedly made by custodial officer in cell where 16-year-old Cleveland Dodd died

image.altText: Donald Trump standing in front of a row of American flags smiling

props.synopsis: Thirty surety companies rejected the former US president and others' applications for a bond to pay off the judgement. He has until March 25 to pay the amount in full.

title.children: Trump risks assets being frozen as 30 companies reject $690m bond applications

image.altText: A phone displaying the meta logo sits on a computer keyboard

props.synopsis: Australia's eSafety commissioner sent six companies legal notices that require them to answer detailed questions on how they are tackling the issue.

title.children: Meta, Google and other social media giants sent legal notices to explain how they combat terrorist and violent extremist material online

image.altText: A woman stands holding the handle bars of a food delivery bike.

props.synopsis: After Joy spoke out about low pay and rider safety she says Hungry Panda retaliated by reducing her delivery orders.

title.children: This food delivery rider spoke up against Hungry Panda. Then they called the police on her

image.altText: four men hug in a shed

props.synopsis: A month after fire devastated the small Victorian town of Pomonal, residents are returning to pick up the pieces. Despite a mammoth fundraising effort, the cost of demolishing the wreckage will prevent many from rebuilding what was lost.

title.children: 'If they haven't cried yet, they might need to': Pomonal tries to rebuild after bushfire 'hell'

image.altText: Ange Postecoglou punches the air

props.synopsis: Ange Postecoglou's Tottenham team will play Newcastle United at the MCG just two days after the EPL season concludes.

title.children: Postecoglou's Tottenham to play at the MCG in May as Arsenal women headline Docklands clash

image.altText: IMAGE LEAD Mar 18

props.synopsis: Australia's chief scientist Cathy Foley tells Q+A that any assessment of energy sources should be guided by evidence.

title.children: Chief scientists backs CSIRO case against 'expensive' nuclear power

image.altText: A football stadium empty

props.synopsis: Queensland Premier Steven Miles ruled out a new stadium in Victoria Park, and a Gabba rebuild. Here's what that means for the 2032 Games.

title.children: The main venues of the 2032 Olympic and Paralympic Games have changed. Here's the new plan

image.altText: A young man sits on his couch and wipes his eyes. He looks hot and tired.

props.synopsis: The results of a temperature-tracking project released today show many renters spent a large chunk of summer in unhealthy and even dangerous temperatures inside their own homes.

title.children: Passing out, calling triple-0 and sleeping in the backyard: This is how renters experienced summer

image.altText: A composite image of Nina Oyama, a Japanese Australian woman, Mel Buttle, and Nazeem Hussain, a Sri Lankan Australian

props.synopsis: We asked Australia's most-loved comedians, including Wil Anderson and Mel Buttle, to give us their picks of the comedy festival.

title.children: Feeling overwhelmed by comedy festival season? We asked our fave comedians who we should see

image.altText: A view of the US Embassy in Havana, Cuba.

props.synopsis: Symptoms of the mysterious ailment, first reported by US embassy officials in the Cuban capital Havana, have included hearing noise and experiencing head pressure followed by headache, migraines, dizziness, and memory lapses.

title.children: US study finds no evidence of brain injury in cases of mysterious 'Havana syndrome'

image.altText: A penguin with some feathers missing in a wooden nesting box.

props.synopsis: Tens of thousands of tourists flock to an island off Perth's southern coast each year to see its population of little penguins, but as numbers of the birds plummet, scientists and volunteers team up to do something about it.

title.children: A once-thriving penguin colony is in danger of dying out, needing shelter from the warming climate

image.altText: A woman with brown hair hugs a young girl in a school dress.

props.synopsis: The Every Week Counts preterm birth prevention program suggests it has prevented about 4,000 Australian babies from being born early each year since 2021.

title.children: Sheree's twins arrived at just 25 weeks. She wants others to know preterm birth prevention is possible
